title: The extraembryonic serosa is a frontier epithelium providing the insect egg with a full-range innate immune response
abstract: <italic>Drosophila</italic> larvae and adults possess a potent innate immune response, but the response of <italic>Drosophila</italic> eggs is poor. In contrast to <italic>Drosophila</italic>, eggs of the beetle <italic>Tribolium</italic> are protected by a serosa, an extraembryonic epithelium that is present in all insects except higher flies. In this study, we test a possible immune function of this frontier epithelium using <italic>Tc-zen1</italic> RNAi-mediated deletion. First, we show that bacteria propagate twice as fast in serosa-less eggs. Then, we compare the complete transcriptomes of wild-type, control RNAi, and <italic>Tc-zen1</italic> RNAi eggs before and after sterile or septic injury. Infection induces genes involved in Toll and IMD-signaling, melanisation, production of reactive oxygen species and antimicrobial peptides in wild-type eggs but not in serosa-less eggs. Finally, we demonstrate constitutive and induced immune gene expression in the serosal epithelium using in situ hybridization. We conclude that the serosa provides insect eggs with a full-range innate immune response.
